title: 105_hr3894
content: The Act may be cited as the "Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act". The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act emphasizes the importance of scientific research and technology development in maintaining air, space, and information superiority. The Act recognizes the historical significance of investing in Air Force research and development, which has benefited American industry and the economy. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act highlights the significance of scientific research and technology development for maintaining air, space, and information superiority. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act emphasizes the importance of dedicating funds to emerging technologies, separating management and funding for science and technology from acquisition, investing in new technology areas, and increasing the number of scientists and engineers with advanced degrees in technical fields within the Air Force. The Air Force Science and Technology Reinvigoration Act aims to increase technical degrees at the master's level for Air Force officers and civilian employees. It also proposes eliminating 5 percent of science and technology programs annually to fund new programs and prevent stagnation. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY FUNCTIONS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE AIR FORCE. Amendments are made to separate the research and development function from the equipping function of the Secretary of the Air Force. This includes establishing a new research and development function within the Office of the Secretary of the Air Force and creating an Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Science and Technology. Amendments establish the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Science and Technology to oversee science and technology functions. Additionally, a Deputy Chief of Staff for Science and Technology is established within the Department of the Air Force. SEC. 5. STUDY. The Secretary of the Air Force must contract the National Research Council to study the Air Force's technology base, recommending minimum requirements for maintaining superiority in air and space weapons systems and information technology. The study should also address the impact of reduced funding on national defense and recommend appropriate staffing levels to ensure the Air Force's science and technology functions remain vital. A report must be submitted within 120 days of completing the study. After the study required by the Secretary of the Air Force is completed, a report on the results must be submitted to Congress.
